advice.Subject: About challenge, growth
advice.Closing Line: Offer full details, clearly state your ask
advice.Overall Messaging: Focus on the goals, achievement. Skip compliments, stay to the point

examples.Subject: Something like 'Fast-growth PM role with a Cloud 100 startup', 'Are you a VP Marketing who can refresh the brand of a F2000 company?' etc.
examples.Salutation: Skip 'Hi', 'Hey' etc., use only the first name
examples.Greeting: Skip usual lines like 'I hope you are doing well'
examples.Closing Line: Something like 'Can we get on a call tomorrow at 1100 hours and I can make sure that you have full information to decide about this opportunity?'
examples.Complimentary Close: Something simple like 'Thanks', 'Regards', or nothing at all.

definitions.Subject: The subject of the email
definitions.Salutation: The very start of a message that addresses the person
definitions.Greeting: The first line after the initial salutation
definitions.Bullet Points: Any bullet points in your message
definitions.Closing Line: The last full line of the mail
definitions.Complimentary Close: The part where you share a goodbye greeting before writing your name
definitions.Tone Of Words: The kind of important phrases and words in your message
definitions.Overall Messaging: The message that you want to convey to the reader
definitions.Length Of Mail: How long the email should be

description: They are motivated by planning, winning, and being part of fast-moving teams and organizations.
They combine a strong bias for action with an analytical bent of mind.
They are not easy to manage as team members and are equally hard taskmasters as leaders.
what_to_say: Tell them how the role would challenge them, and what monetary or growth benefits they can expect.
Use phrases like 'high ROI', 'data-driven culture' etc. if those phrases aptly describe your organization.
Tell them about the authority and control that the position will allow them to exert, if relevant.
what_to_avoid: Don't focus on talking about "friendly workplace", "work life balance" etc., it is quite far from what they truly care about.
Skip verbosity and small talk, they are highly likely to be put off by it.
Don't try to use superlatives or flowery language, they will respond the best if they feel that they are getting the real information.
communication_advice.personalized_email:
Hi <candidate_name>, 

My name is <your_name>, I have been assigned the task to look out for a savvy, analytical <role_name> for <company_name>, based out of <role_location>. From my analysis, I believe that this role should align with your expectations, are you open to a discussion about the same? 

The key expectations from this role are: 
**b**<expectation_first> 
**b**<expectation_second> 
**b**<expectation_third> 

<role_extra_info> 

The most important benefits of this role would be threefold: the chance to work with a pretty sharp team, the ability to make a clear impact, and strong growth prospects. 

Could I give you a call to provide the necessary information that you will need to make your decision? 

I appreciate your time. 

<your_name>
communication_advice.personalized_email_subject: <role_name> role that would enhance your career

examples.Subject: Will this work?', '6.2% revenue impact' etc.
examples.Salutation: Skip 'Hi', 'Hey' etc., use only the first name
examples.Greeting: Skip usual lines like 'I hope you are doing well'
examples.Closing Line: Something like 'Can we get on a call tomorrow at 1100 hours and finalize this?'
examples.Complimentary Close: Something simple like 'Thanks', 'Regards', or nothing at all.

definitions.Subject: The subject of the email
definitions.Salutation: The very start of a message that addresses the person
definitions.Greeting: The first line after the initial salutation
definitions.Bullet Points: Any bullet points in your message
definitions.Closing Line: The last full line of the mail

key_traits.Risk Appetite: They have high risk tolerance and can even take risky decisions easily if their analysis supports it.
key_traits.Ability To Say No: They will say no in a minute if they don’t see value in your product.
key_traits.Speed: They can make decisions quite fast if they have all the necessary information.
key_traits.Decision Drivers: Clear proof of ROI and potential impact are the factors that sway their decision.

description: Once they overcome their initial reluctance, they can be fairly fast adopters.
They prefer to make decisions themselves, after they have done thorough analysis.
They respond better to clear and objective but respectful interactions.
what_to_say: Help them weigh the risks by sharing objective proof points
Stay objective and adopt a professional, business-like approach
Help them see both - the ‘big picture’ impact and the ROI of the investment
what_to_avoid: Don’t focus on relationship, focus purely on the merit of your product
Don’t nudge them to do something by using the logic that others have done the same
Don’t be slow in responding to their emails, requests, questions
